Types

ApplateId = distinct int
index of applate definition in applate cache   Source Edit 
Applate = static ApplateId
static version of ApplateId to use for argument types   Source Edit

Consts

applateTemplateCache = "applates.templates"

the cache containing the anonymous template definition nodes of each applate. can be indexed by the ID of an applate to receive its template node, which is meant to be put in user code and invoked

uses a compileTime seq by default, if you define applatesUseMacroCache then it will use Nim's macrocache types.

  Source Edit

Macros

macro applate(params, body): untyped

creates an applate. when anonymous, returns applate id literal (compatible with Applate/ApplateId). when a name is specified, it defines that name as a constant with the value being the applate id.

note: the return type is untyped by default unlike templates.

Example:

applate foo(name: untyped, val: int):
  let name = val

foo.apply(x, 5)
doAssert x == 5

template double(appl: Applate) =
  appl.apply()
  appl.apply()

var c = 0
when false: # runnableExamples does not handle do: well
  double(applate do:
    double(applate do:
      double(applate do: inc c)))
else:
  double applate(
    double applate(
      double applate(inc(c))))
doAssert c == 8
  Source Edit 
macro apply(appl: Applate; args: varargs[untyped]): untyped
applies the applate by injecting the applate template (if not in scope already) then calling it with the given arguments   Source Edit 
macro `!`(appl: Applate; arg: untyped): untyped
attempted operator syntax for apply. has low precedence though if arg is in parentheses then its arguments are broken up, otherwise it is passed as a single argument   Source Edit

Templates

template applate(body): untyped
creates anonymous applate with no arguments   Source Edit 
template `!=>`(params, body): untyped
infix version of applate, same syntax   Source Edit 
template `!=>`(body): untyped
anonymous applate no arguments   Source Edit 
template `|>`(arg: untyped; appl: Applate): untyped
reversed version of ! with better precedence   Source Edit
